Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: Biogeochemistry of Amazonian Terrestrial Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Deforestation, agricultural expansion and climate change are significant threats to the integrity of ecosystems in the Amazon Basin of South America. The effects of these changes on the cycling of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus and other chemical elements that are essential nutrients for plant and animal life determine how fast vegetation regrows after forests are disturbed, the degree to which various agricultural practices are sustainable, the amounts and types of greenhouse gases that are emitted from soils, and the amount of pollution in groundwater and rivers. Over the last 22 years, the principal investigator of this project has worked with scientists and students from many countries on specific research projects in different parts of the Amazon Basin. Early work showed how important the cycling of soil nutrients is for sustaining cattle pastures with few surviving trees in them, for young re-growing forests, and for older (less disturbed) forests. A big experiment was then conducted where some rain was diverted from an older forest, with the results showing how important water availability is, even in places where it otherwise seems so abundant. Finally, the focus of the most recent research has been on the impacts of more intensive agriculture in the soy and corn cropping systems that have increasingly replaced forests in some parts of the Amazon, along with the role that fire plays in the degradation of forests in the southern part of the Basin. Changes in the Amazon are large scale and rapid, which presents both challenges and opportunities for research. The current project is designed specifically to try and link all of the prior research of the investigator in this region for addressing two main questions. First, how do the relative amounts of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus affect plant growth and the sustainable management of forests, cattle pastures and crop systems across the Amazon Basin? Second, what combinations of these land uses are the most sustainable and how might this change as the climate changes and fire becomes more widespread, as is predicted? In addition to a peer-reviewed monograph for scientific audiences, the investigate will write a book about the importance of nutrient cycling for the sustainability management of Amazonian forests and farms that is intended for a non-specialist audience and will be published in English, Portuguese and Spanish. The book will use real examples of cattle ranching, small-holder farming, large-scale farming, and various types of forest management across the climate gradients of the Amazon Basin, weaving together narratives and data for each.

A major focus of this effort is the identification of circumstances where deforestation, farming and fire affect the balance of soil available nitrogen and phosphorus and their relative importance for plant growth and carbon storage in highly contrasting, but representative, ecosystems. Variation in the ratios of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus is the presumed key that will be pursued. As agriculture and beef production intensify, management of nutrients will become increasingly important and challenging across the entire region. This project will synthesize data and study results from the past quarter century that are central to addressing this issue. The investigator is in a unique position to provide accessible, reliable, important and enjoyable reading for a wide audience on the topics of natural resource management, environmental science and sustainability in the Amazon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Legacies of previous deforestation and continued deforestation in the Amazon Basin are creating more land covered by crops, cattle pastures, and regrowing secondary forests. These changes in land use affect the cycles of essential nutrients for life, such as carbon (C), nitrogen (N), and phosphorus (P). How will altered nutrient cycles affect the possible future fates and functions of these lands, including the possible rates of secondary forest regrowth, soil emissions of greenhouse gases, losses of nutrients to groundwater and stream water, and sustainable management in agroecosystems? The objective of our study was to synthesize multiple datasets from the Amazon region on forest, pasture, and cropland productivity, nutrient cycling, gas emissions, and leaching to demonstrate how land use change impacts the quantities and ratios of C, N, and P in soils, vegetation, and water and how these nutrients limit plant growth within each land-use type.

During the last 20+ years, the PI collaborated with numerous Brazilian and American colleagues in several areas of the Amazon and Cerrado regions. Early work demonstrated the role of nutrient cycling in cattle pastures, secondary forests, and mature forests. Adaptation of mature evergreen forests to the soils and climate of the region were demonstrated in a drought experiment in the Tapajós National Forest. More recently, we studied the impacts on agricultural intensification of soy and corn cropping systems on soil C and N stocks and stream water quality. In this OPUS project we carried out a synthesis of this body of work to demonstrate how the quantities and ratios of C:N:P affect ecosystem productivity and land management sustainability across an array of studied forests, pastures, and cropping systems.

We developed new computer models to compare budgets of stocks and flows of C, N, and P in mature and secondary forests, cattle pastures, and a soybean cropping system. While theses ecosystem budgets in Amazonia are challenging and illuminating exercises in their own right, the ultimate goal was to improve understanding of how nutrient management affects sustainability of agricultural systems and how the use of fire to manage cattle pastures could affect present and future nutrient budgets.

Our results demonstrate that, whereas P is efficiently cycled in all land uses, N losses from fire used to form and maintain cattle pastures deplete available N pools, which ultimately leaves a legacy that can slow secondary forest regrowth. Sequential burns can result in more than 100-times greater N loss than P. These results are consistent with observations of lower rates of N leaching and trace gas emission in deforested and burned areas.

The soils store large stocks of N and P, but the tricky part for our understanding is to determine the rate at which these nutrients are gradually released from the soil in mineral forms that support the growth of pasture grasses and regrowing secondary forest shrubs and trees. Our model estimates this release (mineralization) of soil nutrients at rates generally consistent with observed grass and tree growth, but with two important exceptions. First, although N is lost during fire, the planted pasture grasses have unusually low demand for N relative to P, and so the model predicts a periodic need for P inputs, which is consistent with how ranchers use P fertilizers on their pastures in this region. Second, when the pastures are abandoned and secondary forests are allowed to regrow, the N shortage returns as an important limitation to tree growth. The model predicts a period during secondary forest regrowth when significant N inputs from a process called biological N fixation are needed. This result adds support to a growing body of evidence, including a field study conducted in this project, that biological N fixation is important in regrowing tropical forests, largely due to the legacy of previous fire-induced N losses during forest clearing and pasture management.

During this project, the PI mentored a young Brazilian professor to write up her doctoral dissertation on C and N cycling in soybean fields of the southern Amazon region for publication in an international peer-reviewed journal. An American post-doc did the majority of the nutrient cycling modeling described above, under mentorship of the Pl. She has since successfully obtained a research position with the USDA-ARS.

This project has contributed two papers to the peer-reviewed literature so far and four oral presentations at professional society meetings, including the American Geophysical Union, the European Geosciences Union, and The Brazilian Congress of Soil Science. At the time of this writing, we are on the verge of submitting the nutrient cycle modeling work to the peer-reviewed scientific journal, Ecological Monographs. Taken together, the products of this project have improved understanding of the effects of tropical deforestation, pasture management, crop management, and subsequent forest regrowth on C sequestration, greenhouse gas emissions, water quality, forest resilience, and agricultural sustainability.
